On Tue, 24 Aug 2004 23:04:49 -0000, Kenneth Stanley
<kstanley@...> wrote:
> Those are really nice initial results.  It seems like this is a
> promising research direction.  Some things I'm wondering...How many
> generations does it take to get the "A" discriminator eye?  

We've been trying a bunch of ad hoc experiments, with all sorts of
parameters, so it's difficult to generalize at this point.  But in the
more successful runs, we usually reach 85-95% fitness within around
100 generations, and it normally plateaus out from there.  We've done
up to 500 generations, but we've seen little improvement past the
first 100 or so.

> How much
> CPU time does it require? 

One of our parameters is how much time we give the network based on
its efficiency.  It also depends on the evaluation set of images. 
Currently each network looks at and evaluates 50 images, 25 randomized
A's and 1 of each other letter in the alphabet.  For a population size
of 100, each generation takes about 2 minutes.  I'd say our runs for
100 generations are about 3-4 hours.

> How complex is the network?

Again, this varies widely, since we're trying all sorts of parameters.
 It seems as if, so far, changing the resolution of the eye (e.g. from
4x4 pixels to 10x10) doesn't seem to have a huge impact on evolving
fitness.  We have 5 output nodes, so a fully-connected initial
topology for a 4x4 eye is 131 genes and one for a 10x10 eye is 635
genes.  We're doing blended runs with different mutation settings as
well.  So far we've had very good performers with relatively small
topologies (under a hundred genes).

Derek
